bboxes.raw_text:
For me the be st bread wa S pre-
pared by my venerable Grand
mother Minnie. Many years ago
back home in Indiana, in a dimly
lighted kitchen (due to low wat
tage bulbs), she would pre-


pare some mixture for the next
day S bread.


For treat on Sunday mornings
she would make the lightest,
fluffliest buttermilk biscuits you
ever imagined. My late Grand
father Racker would drown them
in butter and often dip them in
bacon drippings for flavor.


l did not like too many bis
cuits--I enjoyed the outer hard
parts--I could have all of the
scraps and l would roll it flat
and bake 1t until 1t was hard
and crunchy.


Special occa sions we're hot roll
days. One of my aunts was a
great Parkerhouse roll maker.
My Mother made excellent rolls.
too--but her culinary skills shone
on desserts.


| can remember the bread,
butter and sugar days. Nothing
was a s delicious s a couple of
slices of white bread spread
with butter and topped with some
sprinkles of sugar.


Times have changed--breads
have changed--gone are the days
Of hoecakes, corn meal mullins
or homemade loaves.


Gone are the platters heaped
with squares of fresh butter--
gone are the pitchers of honey
now we have some frozen rolls
in the freezer and a few slices
of dry French bread on the table.


If you are looking for some
bread like Mother used to make
or try to make--visit two of my
favorite bake shops--Southside
Bakery or Rix Bakery.

DETROIT The first Negro
airline stewardess. Marlene
White Ahimaz, has joined her
husband, Dr.. Frank Ahimaz, an
engineering teacher with the u S.
Agency for International De-
velopment, in Afghanistan.


Mrs. Ahimaz waged four year
fight to obtain an airline
stewardess job with Northwest
Airlines. In 1862 she was hired,
but wa s discharged 8months later
for inefficiency.


She wa reinstatedb but resigned
soon afterwards when she
married.

One day Patricia Parker asked
her mother a question. but her
mother couldn't answer. She
asked her father and he didn't
know.


Then she asked the barber. He
didn't know. Patricia saw the
milkman. Again she asked her
que stion. He couldn't give her
an answer.


Patricia asked the store clerk,
the blacksmith, the silver smith,
the carpenter, the insurance man
and the mailman.


Everyone was surprised ather
answer. They were ashamed
because they had gone to gram
mar school. high school and COL
lege.


The policeman told them not
to be ashamed because you're
never too old to learn.


Pamela Steed, Julian School,
Grade 6 students are invited to
send their original stories to
the Children s Corner).

The French Revolution was
partly due to the insensible re-
mark of one of the royal para
mour. Madame said IF the poor
have no breed -. let them
eat cake" She lost her head but
the people--the poor ased
and continued to find a few NOR
sells of bread in order to sur
vive.


Hansel and Cretel, of fairy
\ tale fame, managed to outwit
their wicked stepmother by
marking the path with bits of
bread.


The abundance of bread or the
lack of It has controlled the rise
and decline of fabulous empires
and dyna sites.


How many familiar sayings can
) you recall that are ba sed on
bread7 There is the we'll known
phra se--" Taking bread out OF
your mouth" or "Your bread Is
buttered on both Sides"


We're you ever punished or
threatened as a child with the
ia steless dinner of bread and
water7 1t Is still reserved for
some incorrigible prisoners.


The greatest lines in praise
of the staff of life we're probably
written by Omar Khayyam--he
had a recipe for the good life.


All one needed was A
Jug of wine, loaf of bread and
the fright thou beside you In
the wilderness. From then on 1t
would be paradise.


Bread wa once poor man
delight. Now bread is costly.
) A loaf ranges from twenty centsto
forty. We have holeproof bread,
blenderized bread, enriched
bread, purified bread, stone
ground, dieters delight and even
those like your auntie or mother
used to bake.

man, wants all readers to attend.


There will be wide variety of
books suitable for all ages, on
many topics for pre- schoolersto
golden-agers. Many of the selec-
lions are paper backs.


Proceeds will help finance
two scholar ships.

St. Matthew S Home and School
Committee, under the direction
of the Sodality, are sponsoring a
Book Fair on Nov. E, 7 and 9th in
the Cafeteria at 2O38 w. Van
Buren,.


Mrs. Joseph Perlinger, chair
